title: Digital Forensics Methodology
description: Master the end-to-end forensic investigation process from evidence collection through court-ready documentation and reporting.

steps.title: Device Collection and Scene Documentation
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Learn proper procedures for collecting digital evidence and documenting the crime scene to maintain evidentiary integrity.

ACADEMIC BACKGROUND:
Digital forensics begins at the scene where evidence is first encountered. Proper collection procedures ensure that evidence remains admissible in legal proceedings. The principles of digital evidence handling derive from traditional forensic science but require adaptation for the unique properties of electronic data.

KEY PRINCIPLES:
- **Minimize handling**: Reduce opportunities for contamination
- **Document everything**: Create comprehensive records of all actions
- **Maintain chain of custody**: Track evidence from collection to court
- **Preserve original state**: Never modify source evidence
- **Use validated tools**: Employ forensically sound methods

SCENE DOCUMENTATION WORKFLOW:

1. INITIAL ASSESSMENT:
   Before touching any device:
   ```
   Scene Assessment Checklist:
   [ ] Photograph the entire scene (wide shots)
   [ ] Document all visible devices and their state
   [ ] Note any running processes visible on screens
   [ ] Record network connections (cables, wireless indicators)
   [ ] Identify potential volatile evidence
   [ ] Document environmental conditions
   [ ] Identify personnel present
   ```

2. PHOTOGRAPHIC DOCUMENTATION:
   Systematic photography approach:
   - Wide shots: Overall scene context
   - Medium shots: Device placement and connections
   - Close-ups: Screen contents, serial numbers, damage
   - Connection points: Cables, ports, network connections
   
   ```
   Photo Naming Convention:
   CASE-NUMBER_DATE_LOCATION_SEQUENCE.jpg
   Example: 2024-001_20240315_OFFICE1_0001.jpg
   ```

3. DEVICE STATE DOCUMENTATION:
   For each device encountered:
   ```
   Device Documentation Form:
   
   Device ID: DEV-001
   Type: Laptop
   Make/Model: Dell Latitude 5520
   Serial Number: ABC123XYZ
   
   State at Discovery:
   [X] Powered on
   [ ] Powered off
   [ ] Sleep/Hibernate
   [ ] Unknown
   
   Screen Contents: (photograph attached)
   - Email client open
   - Browser with 3 tabs visible
   - Terminal window running
   
   Network Status:
   [X] Ethernet connected
   [ ] WiFi connected
   [X] VPN indicator visible
   
   Peripherals:
   - USB mouse connected
   - External monitor (HDMI)
   - USB drive in port 2 (CRITICAL - document separately)
   
   Physical Condition:
   - Minor scratches on case
   - Sticker on lid (photographed)
   
   Location: Desk in Office 1, Building A
   Collected by: Investigator Name
   Date/Time: 2024-03-15 09:45:00 UTC
   ```

4. VOLATILE EVIDENCE DECISION:
   Critical decision point - powered-on devices:
   
   ```
   Volatile Evidence Assessment:
   
   If device is ON, consider collecting volatile data FIRST:
   - Running processes
   - Network connections
   - Memory contents
   - Logged-in users
   - Clipboard contents
   - Encryption keys in memory
   
   Decision Matrix:
   | Factor | Pull Plug | Capture Live |
   |--------|-----------|-------------|
   | Full disk encryption | No | Yes (keys in RAM) |
   | Active network attack | Maybe | Yes |
   | Standard workstation | Often OK | If time permits |
   | Server with DB | No | Yes |
   | Evidence of anti-forensics | Case-by-case | Document first |
   ```

5. COLLECTION PROCEDURES:
   
   For POWERED OFF devices:
   ```
   1. Document current state (photos, notes)
   2. If laptop: Remove battery if possible
   3. Label all ports and cables before disconnecting
   4. Place in anti-static bag
   5. Seal with evidence tape
   6. Complete chain of custody form
   7. Store in secure, climate-controlled location
   ```
   
   For POWERED ON devices (if pulling plug):
   ```
   1. Document screen contents (photos, video)
   2. Document all running indicators
   3. REMOVE POWER FROM WALL (not shutdown)
   4. For laptops: Remove battery
   5. Label and bag as above
   ```
   
   For LIVE CAPTURE (specialized):
   ```
   1. Document screen and state
   2. Connect write-blocked forensic workstation
   3. Capture volatile data (see Memory Forensics module)
   4. Create forensic image
   5. Then power down as above
   ```

6. CHAIN OF CUSTODY:
   
   ```
   CHAIN OF CUSTODY FORM
   
   Case Number: 2024-FORENSIC-001
   Evidence ID: DEV-001
   Description: Dell Latitude 5520 Laptop
   
   | Date/Time | Released By | Received By | Purpose | Location |
   |-----------|-------------|-------------|---------|----------|
   | 2024-03-15 10:00 | Scene | J. Smith | Collection | Office 1 |
   | 2024-03-15 11:30 | J. Smith | Evidence Room | Storage | Lab |
   | 2024-03-16 08:00 | Evidence Room | A. Jones | Analysis | Lab 2 |
   | 2024-03-16 17:00 | A. Jones | Evidence Room | Return | Lab |
   
   Seal Integrity: [ ] Intact at each transfer
   ```

TOOL REQUIREMENTS:
- Digital camera (or smartphone with timestamp enabled)
- Evidence bags (anti-static for electronics)
- Evidence tape and labels
- Chain of custody forms
- Faraday bags (for mobile devices)
- Write blockers (for live acquisition)
- Documentation templates

DETECTION INDICATORS:
- Complete photographic documentation
- Accurate device state records
- Unbroken chain of custody
- Proper volatile evidence decisions

COMMON PITFALLS:
- Powering on/off devices without documentation
- Failing to photograph screen contents
- Breaking chain of custody
- Not using anti-static protection
- Forgetting to document network state

FURTHER READING:
- NIST SP 800-86: Guide to Integrating Forensic Techniques
- SWGDE Best Practices for Computer Forensics
- ISO/IEC 27037: Digital Evidence Collection

steps.title: Evidence Preservation and Chain of Custody
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Implement evidence preservation procedures that maintain integrity and admissibility throughout the investigation lifecycle.

ACADEMIC BACKGROUND:
Evidence preservation ensures that digital artifacts remain unchanged from collection through analysis and potential court presentation. The chain of custody provides an unbroken documentary record proving evidence integrity. Failure in either area can render evidence inadmissible.

PRESERVATION PRINCIPLES:

1. INTEGRITY PROTECTION:
   ```
   Hash Verification Workflow:
   
   At Collection:
   1. Calculate hash BEFORE any analysis
   2. Use multiple algorithms (MD5 + SHA256)
   3. Document hash values on evidence form
   4. Photograph hash calculation output
   
   Commands:
   # Calculate SHA256 hash
   sha256sum /dev/sda > evidence_hash.txt
   
   # Calculate MD5 (for legacy compatibility)
   md5sum /dev/sda >> evidence_hash.txt
   
   # Verify hash at any point
   sha256sum -c evidence_hash.txt
   
   Example Output:
   Device: /dev/sda
   SHA256: 3a7bd3e2c5e4f6a8b9c0d1e2f3a4b5c6d7e8f9a0b1c2d3e4f5a6b7c8d9e0f1a2
   MD5: a1b2c3d4e5f6a7b8c9d0e1f2a3b4c5d6
   Calculated: 2024-03-15 10:30:00 UTC
   Calculated by: Investigator Name
   ```

2. WRITE PROTECTION:
   Hardware write blockers prevent any modification:
   ```
   Write Blocker Usage:
   
   Physical Write Blockers:
   - Tableau T35u (USB 3.0)
   - WiebeTech USB WriteBlocker
   - Guidance Software Tableau TD3
   
   Connection Order:
   [Evidence Drive] → [Write Blocker] → [Forensic Workstation]
   
   Verification:
   # Check write blocker is active (Linux)
   dmesg | tail -20  # Should show read-only mount
   
   # Verify no write operations possible
   touch /mnt/evidence/test.txt
   # Should fail: Read-only file system
   ```
   
   Software write blocking (Linux):
   ```bash
   # Set device to read-only
   blockdev --setro /dev/sdb
   
   # Verify read-only status
   blockdev --getro /dev/sdb
   # Output: 1 (read-only)
   
   # Mount as read-only with additional protections
   mount -o ro,noexec,noatime /dev/sdb1 /mnt/evidence
   ```

3. STORAGE REQUIREMENTS:
   ```
   Evidence Storage Specifications:
   
   Physical Environment:
   - Temperature: 15-25°C (59-77°F)
   - Humidity: 30-50% relative
   - Protection from magnetic fields
   - Fire-resistant storage
   - Access-controlled area
   
   Digital Storage:
   - RAID arrays with redundancy
   - Regular integrity verification
   - Encrypted storage at rest
   - Offline backup copies
   - Geographic redundancy for critical cases
   
   Retention Schedule:
   | Case Type | Minimum Retention |
   |-----------|------------------|
   | Criminal | Per jurisdiction (often 7+ years) |
   | Civil | Statute of limitations + buffer |
   | HR/Internal | Per policy (typically 3-7 years) |
   | Regulatory | Per requirement (varies) |
   ```

4. CHAIN OF CUSTODY DOCUMENTATION:
   
   Comprehensive tracking form:
   ```
   EVIDENCE TRACKING LOG
   
   Case: 2024-FORENSIC-001
   Evidence ID: IMG-001
   Description: Forensic image of DEV-001 (Dell Laptop HDD)
   Original Hash (SHA256): 3a7bd3e2...
   
   TRANSFER LOG:
   
   Entry 1:
   Date/Time: 2024-03-15 10:30:00
   Action: Created forensic image
   From: Original device (DEV-001)
   To: Forensic workstation
   Handler: J. Smith (Badge #1234)
   Witness: M. Johnson (Badge #5678)
   Hash Verified: YES
   Location: Forensic Lab A
   Notes: Image created using FTK Imager 4.7
   
   Entry 2:
   Date/Time: 2024-03-15 14:00:00
   Action: Copied to analysis workstation
   From: Evidence server
   To: Analysis workstation WS-03
   Handler: A. Jones (Badge #9012)
   Hash Verified: YES
   Location: Analysis Lab B
   Notes: Working copy for examination
   
   SEAL LOG:
   | Seal ID | Applied | Broken | Reason | Witness |
   |---------|---------|--------|--------|----------|
   | SEAL-001 | 2024-03-15 | 2024-03-16 | Analysis | M. Johnson |
   | SEAL-002 | 2024-03-16 | - | Current | - |
   ```

5. VERIFICATION PROCEDURES:
   
   Regular integrity checks:
   ```bash
   # Automated hash verification script
   #!/bin/bash
   
   EVIDENCE_DIR="/forensics/evidence"
   LOG_FILE="/forensics/logs/integrity_$(date +%Y%m%d).log"
   
   echo "Integrity Check: $(date)" >> $LOG_FILE
   
   for img in $EVIDENCE_DIR/*.E01; do
       stored_hash=$(grep "$img" /forensics/hashes/master.txt | cut -d' ' -f1)
       current_hash=$(ewfverify "$img" 2>/dev/null | grep "SHA256" | awk '{print $2}')
       
       if [ "$stored_hash" == "$current_hash" ]; then
           echo "PASS: $img" >> $LOG_FILE
       else
           echo "FAIL: $img - ALERT REQUIRED" >> $LOG_FILE
           # Send alert to forensics team
       fi
   done
   ```

6. LEGAL CONSIDERATIONS:
   ```
   Evidence Admissibility Factors:
   
   1. Authentication
      - Can you prove the evidence is what you claim?
      - Hash values, chain of custody, witness testimony
   
   2. Reliability
      - Were forensically sound methods used?
      - Were tools validated and documented?
   
   3. Completeness
      - Is the evidence complete and unaltered?
      - Can gaps in custody be explained?
   
   4. Expert Testimony
      - Can examiner explain methodology?
      - Are credentials and experience documented?
   ```

DETECTION INDICATORS:
- Hash values match at all verification points
- Complete chain of custody documentation
- Write protection verified and logged
- Proper storage conditions maintained

COMMON PITFALLS:
- Forgetting to hash before imaging
- Gaps in chain of custody documentation
- Using write blockers incorrectly
- Inadequate storage environment
- Not documenting tool versions

FURTHER READING:
- SWGDE Guidelines for Evidence Handling
- ACPO Good Practice Guide for Digital Evidence
- Federal Rules of Evidence (US)

steps.title: Forensic Acquisition Methods
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Master various forensic acquisition techniques including live vs. dead acquisition, logical vs. physical imaging, and tool selection.

ACADEMIC BACKGROUND:
Forensic acquisition creates exact copies of digital evidence for analysis. The acquisition method depends on device state, encryption status, time constraints, and legal requirements. Understanding each method's strengths and limitations is critical for choosing the appropriate approach.

ACQUISITION TYPES:

1. PHYSICAL ACQUISITION:
   Bit-for-bit copy of entire storage medium:
   ```
   Captures:
   - All allocated data
   - Deleted files (unallocated space)
   - File slack space
   - Hidden partitions
   - Host protected area (HPA)
   - Device configuration overlay (DCO)
   
   When to Use:
   - Complete evidence preservation required
   - Deleted file recovery needed
   - Hidden data suspected
   - Time permits full acquisition
   
   Commands (Linux dd):
   # Basic physical acquisition
   dc3dd if=/dev/sdb of=/forensics/case001/evidence.dd hash=sha256 log=/forensics/case001/acquisition.log
   
   # With progress and verification
   dc3dd if=/dev/sdb of=/forensics/case001/evidence.dd hash=sha256 hlog=/forensics/case001/hash.log log=/forensics/case001/dd.log verb=on
   
   # Using FTK Imager (command line)
   ftkimager /dev/sdb /forensics/case001/evidence --e01 --compress 6 --verify
   ```

2. LOGICAL ACQUISITION:
   Copy of files and folders through the file system:
   ```
   Captures:
   - User-accessible files and folders
   - File metadata (timestamps, permissions)
   - Directory structure
   
   Does NOT Capture:
   - Deleted files
   - Unallocated space
   - Slack space
   - Hidden partitions
   
   When to Use:
   - Time-critical situations
   - Cloud storage or network shares
   - Mobile device extraction (some methods)
   - Targeted collection (specific files)
   
   Commands:
   # Logical copy with metadata preservation
   robocopy E:\ /forensics/logical /E /COPYALL /LOG:copy.log
   
   # Linux with tar
   tar -cvpf /forensics/logical.tar --xattrs /mnt/evidence/
   
   # With rsync preserving everything
   rsync -aAXv --progress /mnt/evidence/ /forensics/logical/
   ```

3. LIVE ACQUISITION:
   Collecting from running systems:
   ```
   When Required:
   - Full disk encryption (BitLocker, FileVault, LUKS)
   - Server systems that cannot be shut down
   - Active intrusion investigation
   - Volatile evidence collection
   
   Live Memory Acquisition:
   # Windows - WinPmem
   winpmem_mini_x64.exe output.raw
   
   # Linux - LiME
   insmod lime.ko "path=/forensics/memory.lime format=lime"
   
   # macOS - osxpmem
   sudo ./osxpmem.app/osxpmem -o memory.raw
   
   Live Disk Acquisition:
   # FTK Imager (Windows GUI) - supports live systems
   # Capture logical image while system running
   
   # Linux live acquisition
   dc3dd if=/dev/sda of=/forensics/live.dd hash=sha256
   ```

4. DEAD ACQUISITION:
   Collecting from powered-off systems:
   ```
   Standard Approach:
   1. Remove storage device from system
   2. Connect to forensic workstation via write blocker
   3. Create forensic image
   4. Verify hash values
   
   Boot Disk Methods:
   # Paladin Forensic Suite (bootable Linux)
   # Boots from USB, mounts drives read-only by default
   
   # CAINE (Computer Aided INvestigative Environment)
   # Forensic Linux distribution
   
   Advantages:
   - No risk of evidence modification
   - Full access to all disk areas
   - Simpler hash verification
   ```

5. IMAGE FORMATS:
   ```
   Raw/DD Format:
   - Bit-for-bit copy
   - No compression
   - Universal compatibility
   - Large file sizes
   Extension: .dd, .raw, .img
   
   E01 (EnCase Evidence File):
   - Compression support
   - Built-in hash verification
   - Case metadata storage
   - Segment file support
   Extension: .E01, .E02, etc.
   
   AFF (Advanced Forensic Format):
   - Open format
   - Compression and encryption
   - Metadata support
   - Arbitrary data storage
   Extension: .aff, .afd
   
   Comparison:
   | Format | Compression | Metadata | Compatibility | Size |
   |--------|-------------|----------|---------------|------|
   | Raw | No | No | Universal | Large |
   | E01 | Yes | Yes | Wide | Medium |
   | AFF | Yes | Yes | Growing | Medium |
   ```

6. ACQUISITION WORKFLOW:
   ```
   Standard Acquisition Procedure:
   
   1. PREPARATION
      [ ] Document source device (photos, serial numbers)
      [ ] Calculate source hash if possible
      [ ] Prepare destination with sufficient space
      [ ] Connect write blocker and verify
   
   2. ACQUISITION
      [ ] Start imaging tool
      [ ] Verify write protection active
      [ ] Begin acquisition with hash calculation
      [ ] Monitor for errors
   
   3. VERIFICATION
      [ ] Compare source and destination hashes
      [ ] Document any errors or issues
      [ ] Create working copy if needed
      [ ] Store original image securely
   
   4. DOCUMENTATION
      [ ] Complete acquisition log
      [ ] Update chain of custody
      [ ] Store hash values securely
   ```

7. PRACTICAL COMMANDS:
   ```bash
   # Complete acquisition with dc3dd
   dc3dd if=/dev/sdb \
         hof=/forensics/case001/evidence.dd \
         hash=sha256 \
         hlog=/forensics/case001/hash.log \
         rec=off \
         log=/forensics/case001/acquisition.log
   
   # EWF (E01) creation with ewfacquire
   ewfacquire /dev/sdb \
              -t /forensics/case001/evidence \
              -C case001 \
              -D "Evidence description" \
              -e "Examiner name" \
              -E "Evidence number" \
              -m physical \
              -c best \
              -S 2G
   
   # Verify E01 image
   ewfverify /forensics/case001/evidence.E01
   ```

DETECTION INDICATORS:
- Successful image creation with matching hashes
- Complete acquisition log documentation
- Appropriate method selection for scenario
- Proper write protection verification

COMMON PITFALLS:
- Acquiring without write blocker
- Not verifying hash after acquisition
- Insufficient destination storage space
- Wrong acquisition type for situation
- Not documenting acquisition parameters

FURTHER READING:
- NIST SP 800-86: Forensic Acquisition Guidelines
- Guidance Software EnCase documentation
- dc3dd documentation

steps.title: Evidence Processing Workflows
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Establish systematic procedures for processing forensic images to extract and organize evidentiary data.

ACADEMIC BACKGROUND:
Evidence processing transforms raw forensic images into analyzed, searchable data. This phase bridges acquisition and analysis, applying automated tools to extract artifacts, index content, and prepare evidence for examination. Efficient processing workflows reduce analysis time and ensure consistent results.

PROCESSING PIPELINE:

1. IMAGE VERIFICATION AND MOUNTING:
   ```bash
   # Verify image integrity before processing
   ewfverify /forensics/case001/evidence.E01
   
   # Mount E01 image for processing
   ewfmount /forensics/case001/evidence.E01 /mnt/ewf/
   
   # Mount raw image (read-only, loop device)
   losetup -r /dev/loop0 /forensics/case001/evidence.dd
   mount -o ro,noexec /dev/loop0 /mnt/evidence/
   
   # For images with partitions
   kpartx -av /forensics/case001/evidence.dd
   mount -o ro /dev/mapper/loop0p1 /mnt/evidence/
   ```

2. AUTOMATED EXTRACTION:
   
   Using Bulk Extractor:
   ```bash
   # Extract all supported artifact types
   bulk_extractor -o /forensics/case001/bulk_output \
                  -R /mnt/ewf/ewf1
   
   # Extract specific features only
   bulk_extractor -o /forensics/case001/bulk_output \
                  -E email \
                  -E url \
                  -E domain \
                  /mnt/ewf/ewf1
   
   # Output files generated:
   # email.txt - Email addresses found
   # domain.txt - Domain names
   # url.txt - URLs
   # telephone.txt - Phone numbers
   # ccn.txt - Credit card numbers
   # ip.txt - IP addresses
   ```
   
   Using Autopsy (command line):
   ```bash
   # Create new case and add data source
   autopsy --create-case /forensics/autopsy/case001 \
           --case-name "Case001" \
           --add-data-source /forensics/case001/evidence.E01
   
   # Run ingest modules
   autopsy --run-ingest \
           --case /forensics/autopsy/case001 \
           --modules "hash,keyword,email,web"
   ```

3. FILE SYSTEM ANALYSIS:
   
   Using The Sleuth Kit:
   ```bash
   # List partitions in image
   mmls /forensics/case001/evidence.dd
   
   # Example output:
   # DOS Partition Table
   # Offset Sector: 0
   # Units are in 512-byte sectors
   #
   #      Slot      Start        End          Length       Description
   # 000:  Meta      0000000000   0000000000   0000000001   Primary Table (#0)
   # 001:  -------   0000000000   0000002047   0000002048   Unallocated
   # 002:  000:000   0000002048   0976771071   0976769024   NTFS (0x07)
   
   # List files in partition
   fls -r -o 2048 /forensics/case001/evidence.dd > /forensics/case001/file_listing.txt
   
   # Extract specific file by inode
   icat -o 2048 /forensics/case001/evidence.dd 12345 > /forensics/case001/recovered_file.docx
   
   # Generate timeline
   fls -r -m "/" -o 2048 /forensics/case001/evidence.dd > /forensics/case001/body.txt
   mactime -b /forensics/case001/body.txt > /forensics/case001/timeline.csv
   ```

4. HASH CALCULATION AND DEDUPLICATION:
   ```bash
   # Calculate hashes for all files
   find /mnt/evidence -type f -exec sha256sum {} \; > /forensics/case001/file_hashes.txt
   
   # Using md5deep for recursive hashing
   md5deep -r /mnt/evidence > /forensics/case001/md5_hashes.txt
   
   # Compare against known file hash databases
   # NSRL (National Software Reference Library)
   hfind -i nsrl-sha1 /forensics/hashsets/nsrl.idx /forensics/case001/file_hashes.txt
   
   # Identify known good files (filtering)
   grep -v "Known" /forensics/case001/file_hashes.txt > /forensics/case001/unknown_files.txt
   ```

5. KEYWORD INDEXING:
   ```bash
   # Index image for keyword searching (using Autopsy CLI)
   # Or create searchable index with grep/awk
   
   # Extract all text content
   strings -a /forensics/case001/evidence.dd > /forensics/case001/strings.txt
   
   # Search for specific keywords
   grep -i -n "password\|secret\|confidential" /forensics/case001/strings.txt > /forensics/case001/keyword_hits.txt
   
   # Create word frequency analysis
   cat /forensics/case001/strings.txt | \
       tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]' | \
       tr -cs '[:alpha:]' '\n' | \
       sort | uniq -c | sort -rn | head -100 > /forensics/case001/word_freq.txt
   ```

6. ARTIFACT EXTRACTION:
   ```bash
   # Browser history extraction
   # Chrome (Linux location)
   cp "/mnt/evidence/Users/*/AppData/Local/Google/Chrome/User Data/Default/History" \
      /forensics/case001/artifacts/
   
   # Parse SQLite databases
   sqlite3 /forensics/case001/artifacts/History \
       "SELECT url, title, visit_count, datetime(last_visit_time/1000000-11644473600,'unixepoch') 
        FROM urls ORDER BY last_visit_time DESC LIMIT 100;"
   
   # Registry extraction (Windows)
   # Export registry hives for analysis
   cp /mnt/evidence/Windows/System32/config/SAM /forensics/case001/registry/
   cp /mnt/evidence/Windows/System32/config/SYSTEM /forensics/case001/registry/
   cp /mnt/evidence/Windows/System32/config/SOFTWARE /forensics/case001/registry/
   cp /mnt/evidence/Windows/System32/config/SECURITY /forensics/case001/registry/
   cp "/mnt/evidence/Users/*/NTUSER.DAT" /forensics/case001/registry/
   ```

7. PROCESSING DOCUMENTATION:
   ```
   Evidence Processing Log
   
   Case: 2024-FORENSIC-001
   Evidence: IMG-001
   Processing Date: 2024-03-16
   Examiner: A. Jones
   
   Tools Used:
   | Tool | Version | Purpose | Output |
   |------|---------|---------|--------|
   | ewfverify | 20171104 | Image verification | PASSED |
   | bulk_extractor | 2.0 | Artifact extraction | bulk_output/ |
   | TSK fls | 4.11.1 | File listing | file_listing.txt |
   | mactime | 4.11.1 | Timeline | timeline.csv |
   | sqlite3 | 3.36 | DB parsing | artifacts/ |
   
   Processing Summary:
   - Total files extracted: 145,672
   - Known files (NSRL): 98,234 (67.4%)
   - Files requiring review: 47,438
   - Keyword hits: 1,247
   - Email addresses found: 892
   - URLs found: 15,678
   
   Anomalies/Notes:
   - Encrypted container found at Users/John/Private/vault.tc
   - Evidence of file wiping tool execution
   - Timestamps suggest clock manipulation
   ```

DETECTION INDICATORS:
- All expected artifact types extracted
- Processing completed without errors
- Timeline data generated successfully
- Keyword index searchable

COMMON PITFALLS:
- Processing mounted image as read-write
- Not documenting tool versions
- Incomplete artifact extraction
- Not filtering known files
- Missing timeline creation

FURTHER READING:
- Bulk Extractor documentation
- Autopsy User Guide
- The Sleuth Kit Wiki

steps.title: Analysis Techniques and Methodologies
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Apply structured analysis methodologies to forensic evidence to establish facts, timelines, and conclusions.

ACADEMIC BACKGROUND:
Forensic analysis transforms processed data into investigative findings. It requires systematic examination of artifacts, correlation of events, and critical evaluation of evidence. The analyst must maintain objectivity, document assumptions, and distinguish between facts and inferences.

ANALYSIS METHODOLOGIES:

1. TIMELINE ANALYSIS:
   ```
   Timeline Construction:
   
   Sources of timestamp evidence:
   - File system timestamps (MAC times)
   - Event logs
   - Browser history
   - Email headers
   - Application logs
   - Registry timestamps
   
   MAC Times Explained:
   - Modified (M): Content changed
   - Accessed (A): File opened/read
   - Changed (C): Metadata modified (permissions, ownership)
   - Birth (B): File created (not all file systems)
   
   Timeline Analysis Commands:
   ```bash
   # Generate comprehensive timeline
   log2timeline.py --storage-file case001.plaso /mnt/evidence/
   
   # Filter and export timeline
   psort.py -o l2tcsv -w /forensics/case001/timeline.csv case001.plaso
   
   # Filter by date range
   psort.py -o l2tcsv \
            --slice "2024-03-01 00:00:00" \
            --slice_size 7d \
            -w /forensics/case001/march_week1.csv case001.plaso
   ```
   
   Timeline Analysis Template:
   ```
   | Timestamp | Source | Event Type | Details | Significance |
   |-----------|--------|------------|---------|-------------|
   | 2024-03-14 09:15 | EventLog | Logon | User: jsmith, Type: Interactive | Start of session |
   | 2024-03-14 09:18 | Prefetch | Execution | chrome.exe | Normal activity |
   | 2024-03-14 09:45 | USN Journal | File Create | C:\Temp\payload.exe | SUSPICIOUS |
   | 2024-03-14 09:45 | EventLog | Process Create | payload.exe | Malware execution |
   | 2024-03-14 09:46 | Registry | Key Modified | Run key added | Persistence |
   ```

2. ARTIFACT CORRELATION:
   ```
   Cross-Reference Analysis:
   
   Example: Proving file download
   
   Evidence Sources:
   1. Browser History - URL visited
   2. Browser Cache - File cached
   3. Download folder - File present
   4. Zone.Identifier - Marked as downloaded
   5. Prefetch - Application executed
   
   Correlation Matrix:
   | Evidence | Supports | Timestamp | Confidence |
   |----------|----------|-----------|------------|
   | Browser URL | Download initiated | 09:42:15 | High |
   | Cache file | Content received | 09:42:18 | High |
   | Downloads folder | File saved | 09:42:20 | High |
   | Zone.Identifier | Internet origin | 09:42:20 | High |
   | Prefetch | File executed | 09:43:01 | High |
   
   Conclusion: User downloaded and executed file at ~09:43
   ```

3. USER ACTIVITY RECONSTRUCTION:
   ```
   User Profile Analysis Checklist:
   
   [ ] Recent documents (LNK files)
   [ ] Browser history and bookmarks
   [ ] Email sent/received
   [ ] USB device history
   [ ] Application usage (Prefetch, UserAssist)
   [ ] Search history (Windows Search, browser)
   [ ] Cloud storage sync (OneDrive, Dropbox)
   [ ] Recycle Bin contents
   [ ] Shellbags (folder access)
   
   Reconstructing Actions:
   ```bash
   # Parse Windows LNK files
   python3 lnk_parser.py /forensics/case001/artifacts/Recent/*.lnk
   
   # Analyze UserAssist (ROT13 encoded)
   regripper -r /forensics/case001/registry/NTUSER.DAT -p userassist
   
   # Parse Prefetch files
   python3 prefetch_parser.py /forensics/case001/artifacts/Prefetch/
   ```

4. MALWARE ANALYSIS INTEGRATION:
   ```
   Suspicious File Triage:
   
   1. Static Analysis:
   # File type verification
   file suspicious.exe
   
   # String extraction
   strings -a suspicious.exe | less
   
   # PE header analysis
   peframe suspicious.exe
   
   # Hash lookup
   sha256sum suspicious.exe
   # Check against VirusTotal, Malware Bazaar
   
   2. Behavioral Indicators (from forensic artifacts):
   - Persistence mechanisms created
   - Network connections established
   - Files created/modified
   - Registry changes
   
   3. YARA Scanning:
   yara -r /forensics/rules/malware/ /mnt/evidence/
   ```

5. ANTI-FORENSICS DETECTION:
   ```
   Indicators of Anti-Forensics:
   
   Timestamp Manipulation:
   - $STANDARD_INFORMATION different from $FILE_NAME
   - Timestamps inconsistent with surrounding events
   - "Future" timestamps
   
   ```bash
   # Compare SI and FN timestamps (NTFS)
   analyzeMFT.py -f /forensics/case001/MFT -o /forensics/case001/mft_analysis.csv
   # Look for discrepancies in output
   ```
   
   Data Destruction:
   - Wiping tool artifacts (CCleaner, Eraser)
   - Large gaps in file system allocation
   - Prefetch for wiping tools
   
   Hidden Data:
   - Alternate data streams
   - Slack space hiding
   - Steganography indicators
   
   ```bash
   # Find alternate data streams
   find /mnt/evidence -type f -exec getfattr -d {} \; 2>/dev/null | grep -v "^#"
   
   # Scan for steganography
   stegdetect /forensics/case001/images/*.jpg
   ```

6. HYPOTHESIS TESTING:
   ```
   Scientific Method for Forensics:
   
   1. Observation: Review initial evidence
   2. Hypothesis: Form testable theory
   3. Prediction: What evidence should exist if true?
   4. Testing: Search for supporting/contradicting evidence
   5. Conclusion: Accept, reject, or revise hypothesis
   
   Example:
   Hypothesis: User exfiltrated data via USB
   
   Predictions:
   - USB device connection in registry
   - File copy events in USN journal
   - Files in USB root directory
   - Timestamp correlation
   
   Testing:
   - Registry: USB device found, first connected 2024-03-14 08:00
   - USN Journal: 847 file copies to removable drive
   - Shellbags: Access to E:\ drive recorded
   - No contradicting evidence found
   
   Conclusion: SUPPORTED - Evidence consistent with USB exfiltration
   ```

DETECTION INDICATORS:
- Timeline constructed with multiple sources
- Artifact correlation documented
- Hypotheses tested with evidence
- Anti-forensics indicators identified

COMMON PITFALLS:
- Confirmation bias in analysis
- Ignoring contradictory evidence
- Over-interpreting limited data
- Not documenting analytical reasoning
- Missing anti-forensics indicators

FURTHER READING:
- SANS FOR500/508 Analysis Methodologies
- log2timeline/Plaso documentation
- Digital Forensics with Kali Linux

steps.title: Documentation and Reporting Standards
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Produce professional forensic reports that clearly communicate findings and withstand legal scrutiny.

ACADEMIC BACKGROUND:
Forensic documentation serves multiple purposes: preserving the analytical process, communicating findings to stakeholders, and providing evidence for legal proceedings. Reports must be accurate, complete, objective, and understandable to both technical and non-technical audiences.

REPORT STRUCTURE:

1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:
   ```
   Example Executive Summary:
   
   DIGITAL FORENSIC EXAMINATION REPORT
   Case Number: 2024-FORENSIC-001
   
   EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
   
   At the request of [Organization], a forensic examination was conducted
   on computing equipment seized from [Location] on [Date]. The examination
   focused on determining whether [Subject] engaged in [Alleged Activity].
   
   KEY FINDINGS:
   
   1. Evidence of unauthorized data access was identified, including:
      - 847 files copied to a USB device on March 14, 2024
      - Files included confidential customer records
      - Activity occurred outside normal business hours
   
   2. Attempts to conceal activity were detected:
      - Browser history cleared on March 15, 2024
      - File deletion tool executed on March 15, 2024
      - Original files remain recoverable from unallocated space
   
   3. Timeline establishes activity occurred between March 12-15, 2024
   
   CONCLUSIONS:
   The evidence supports a finding that [Subject] copied sensitive data
   to external media and subsequently attempted to destroy evidence of
   this activity. The recovered data establishes both the scope of the
   breach and the intent to conceal.
   ```

2. DETAILED FINDINGS SECTION:
   ```
   Section 4: Detailed Findings
   
   4.1 USB Device Activity
   
   Finding: A USB storage device was connected to the examined computer
   on March 14, 2024, and used to copy files.
   
   Evidence:
   - Registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Enum\USBSTOR contains
     entry for "SanDisk Cruzer" (Serial: 4C530001234567)
   - First connection timestamp: 2024-03-14 08:15:32 UTC
   - Last connection timestamp: 2024-03-14 08:45:18 UTC
   
   Supporting Artifacts:
   - setupapi.dev.log entry (Exhibit A-1)
   - Registry export (Exhibit A-2)
   - USN Journal entries (Exhibit A-3)
   
   Analysis:
   The registry evidence establishes that a specific USB device was
   connected during the timeframe of interest. Cross-reference with
   USN Journal entries shows 847 file operations to drive letter E:
   during this 30-minute window.
   
   [Continue with additional findings...]
   ```

3. METHODOLOGY DOCUMENTATION:
   ```
   Section 2: Methodology
   
   2.1 Evidence Handling
   All evidence was handled in accordance with [Organization] procedures
   and SWGDE best practices. Write-blocking hardware was used for all
   acquisitions. Chain of custody was maintained throughout.
   
   2.2 Acquisition
   Forensic images were created using [Tool, Version]. Acquisition
   details are provided in Appendix B. All images were verified using
   SHA-256 hash comparison.
   
   2.3 Processing
   Images were processed using the following tools:
   - Autopsy 4.19.3 - Primary analysis platform
   - Bulk Extractor 2.0 - Artifact extraction
   - RegRipper 3.0 - Registry analysis
   - log2timeline 20231012 - Timeline creation
   
   2.4 Analysis
   Analysis followed a systematic approach:
   1. Timeline construction from all available sources
   2. User activity reconstruction
   3. Artifact correlation
   4. Hypothesis testing
   
   2.5 Limitations
   - Examination limited to provided evidence items
   - Encrypted container (vault.tc) could not be accessed
   - Some log files had been deleted prior to seizure
   ```

4. EXHIBIT PREPARATION:
   ```
   Exhibit Standards:
   
   Each exhibit should include:
   - Unique identifier (e.g., Exhibit A-1)
   - Description of what it shows
   - Source location in evidence
   - Tool used to extract/view
   - Hash value of source file
   
   Example Exhibit:
   
   ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   EXHIBIT A-1: USB Device Registry Entry
   
   Source: Evidence Item DEV-001
   Location: SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Enum\USBSTOR
   Extracted with: RegRipper 3.0
   
   Content:
   [USBSTOR\Disk&Ven_SanDisk&Prod_Cruzer&Rev_1.00\4C530001234567]
   DeviceDesc="SanDisk Cruzer USB Device"
   FriendlyName="SanDisk Cruzer USB Device"
   Service="disk"
   
   Significance: Establishes specific USB device connection
   ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   ```

5. TECHNICAL APPENDICES:
   ```
   Appendix A: Evidence Inventory
   
   | Item ID | Description | Serial/ID | Hash (SHA-256) |
   |---------|-------------|-----------|----------------|
   | DEV-001 | Dell Laptop | SVC-12345 | N/A |
   | IMG-001 | DEV-001 Image | - | 3a7bd3e2... |
   | DEV-002 | USB Drive | 4C53000... | N/A |
   | IMG-002 | DEV-002 Image | - | 8f9c2d1a... |
   
   Appendix B: Acquisition Logs
   [Include full dc3dd/FTK Imager logs]
   
   Appendix C: Tool Validation
   [Document tool testing and validation]
   
   Appendix D: Examiner Credentials
   [CV, certifications, training]
   ```

6. REPORT WRITING BEST PRACTICES:
   ```
   Language Guidelines:
   
   DO:
   - Use objective, neutral language
   - Clearly distinguish facts from interpretations
   - Cite specific evidence for each finding
   - Acknowledge limitations and uncertainties
   - Use consistent terminology
   
   DON'T:
   - Use emotional or judgmental language
   - Make unsupported conclusions
   - Speculate beyond the evidence
   - Use jargon without explanation
   - Editorialize about guilt or innocence
   
   Examples:
   
   WRONG: "The suspect obviously tried to hide his crimes"
   RIGHT: "Evidence of file deletion using CCleaner was identified"
   
   WRONG: "The user stole company data"
   RIGHT: "Files were copied to external media outside authorized procedures"
   ```

7. QUALITY ASSURANCE:
   ```
   Report Review Checklist:
   
   [ ] All findings supported by cited evidence
   [ ] Methodology clearly documented
   [ ] Chain of custody complete
   [ ] Hash values verified and documented
   [ ] Exhibits properly formatted
   [ ] Technical accuracy verified
   [ ] Grammar and spelling checked
   [ ] Conclusions follow logically from findings
   [ ] Limitations acknowledged
   [ ] Peer review completed
   ```

DETECTION INDICATORS:
- Complete, accurate documentation
- Findings supported by evidence
- Clear methodology description
- Professional presentation

COMMON PITFALLS:
- Unsupported conclusions
- Missing chain of custody
- Technical jargon without explanation
- Incomplete methodology documentation
- Bias in language or analysis

FURTHER READING:
- SWGDE Model Quality Assurance Manual
- NIST Forensic Science Research and Development
- Scientific Working Group on Digital Evidence publications

steps.title: Legal Considerations and Expert Testimony
steps.content:
OBJECTIVE: Understand legal requirements for digital evidence and prepare for potential expert witness testimony.

ACADEMIC BACKGROUND:
Digital evidence must meet legal standards for admissibility. Forensic examiners may be called to testify as expert witnesses, requiring preparation to explain technical findings to judges and juries. Understanding the legal framework ensures evidence and testimony will be effective.

EVIDENCE ADMISSIBILITY:

1. DAUBERT STANDARD (US Federal Courts):
   ```
   Factors for Scientific Evidence Admissibility:
   
   1. TESTABILITY
      - Can the technique be tested?
      - Forensic imaging: YES - hash verification proves accuracy
   
   2. PEER REVIEW
      - Has method been peer-reviewed and published?
      - Standard forensic methods: Extensively documented
   
   3. ERROR RATE
      - What is the known or potential error rate?
      - Digital forensics: Documented validation studies exist
   
   4. STANDARDS
      - Are there standards controlling the technique?
      - Yes: NIST, SWGDE, ISO 27037
   
   5. GENERAL ACCEPTANCE
      - Is the method generally accepted in the field?
      - Mainstream forensic techniques: Widely accepted
   ```

2. AUTHENTICATION REQUIREMENTS:
   ```
   Authenticating Digital Evidence:
   
   The proponent must show evidence is what it claims to be.
   
   Methods:
   - Hash verification (mathematical proof of integrity)
   - Chain of custody documentation
   - Expert testimony on collection methods
   - Circumstantial evidence of authenticity
   
   Example Foundation Questions:
   Q: "Can you identify Exhibit 1?"
   A: "This is a forensic image of the hard drive from the laptop
       collected at the scene."
   
   Q: "How do you know this is an accurate copy?"
   A: "I calculated a SHA-256 hash of the original drive before
       imaging. The hash value matched after imaging was complete,
       mathematically proving the copy is identical."
   
   Q: "Has the evidence been altered since collection?"
   A: "No. I re-verified the hash value before analysis, and it
       matched the original value recorded at collection."
   ```

3. EXPERT WITNESS PREPARATION:
   ```
   Qualification Process:
   
   Before testifying to opinions, expert must be qualified:
   
   Expected Questions:
   - Educational background
   - Professional certifications (GCFE, EnCE, CCE, etc.)
   - Years of experience
   - Number of examinations performed
   - Previous testimony experience
   - Publications or teaching experience
   - Relevant training courses
   
   Sample CV Section:
   
   QUALIFICATIONS:
   - B.S. Computer Science, [University], [Year]
   - Certified Computer Examiner (CCE), [Year]
   - GIAC Certified Forensic Examiner (GCFE), [Year]
   - EnCase Certified Examiner (EnCE), [Year]
   - 10 years digital forensics experience
   - 500+ forensic examinations completed
   - Testified as expert witness 25+ times
   - Instructor, [Training Organization]
   ```

4. TESTIMONY PREPARATION:
   ```
   Pre-Testimony Checklist:
   
   [ ] Review entire case file
   [ ] Review report and all exhibits
   [ ] Prepare demonstrative exhibits (if allowed)
   [ ] Meet with counsel to discuss questions
   [ ] Anticipate cross-examination challenges
   [ ] Review opposing expert report (if any)
   [ ] Prepare explanations for technical concepts
   [ ] Dress professionally
   [ ] Arrive early and review courtroom setup
   
   Communication Guidelines:
   
   - Speak clearly and at appropriate pace
   - Face the jury when answering
   - Use plain language, define technical terms
   - Be confident but not arrogant
   - Admit limitations of knowledge or evidence
   - Never guess - "I don't know" is acceptable
   - Take time to think before answering
   - Don't volunteer information beyond the question
   ```

5. CROSS-EXAMINATION CHALLENGES:
   ```
   Common Defense Challenges:
   
   1. Chain of Custody Attacks:
   Q: "Isn't it true there was a gap in your chain of custody?"
   Preparation: Ensure documentation is complete; if gaps exist,
   explain procedures that maintained integrity.
   
   2. Tool Reliability:
   Q: "Has your tool ever produced incorrect results?"
   Preparation: Know tool validation studies; acknowledge that
   all tools can have errors but explain verification methods.
   
   3. Alternative Explanations:
   Q: "Couldn't this evidence have been planted?"
   Preparation: Explain what evidence of tampering would look like;
   describe why findings are inconsistent with tampering.
   
   4. Timestamp Manipulation:
   Q: "Can't timestamps be easily changed?"
   Preparation: Yes, but explain how multiple corroborating
   timestamps and anti-forensics detection mitigate this.
   
   5. Competency Challenge:
   Q: "You're not a certified [specific certification], are you?"
   Preparation: Emphasize relevant experience and training;
   certification isn't legally required for testimony.
   ```

6. DEMONSTRATIVE EXHIBITS:
   ```
   Visual Aids for Technical Concepts:
   
   Timeline Visualization:
   - Color-coded event timeline
   - Highlight critical moments
   - Show before/after comparisons
   
   Process Diagrams:
   - How hash verification works
   - Evidence flow from scene to lab
   - Attack sequence reconstruction
   
   Comparison Charts:
   - Source vs. destination file properties
   - Normal vs. suspicious activity patterns
   
   Note: All demonstratives must be:
   - Accurate representations of evidence
   - Approved by counsel before use
   - Not unfairly prejudicial
   ```

7. REGULATORY CONSIDERATIONS:
   ```
   Key Regulations Affecting Digital Evidence:
   
   Privacy Laws:
   - GDPR (EU) - Data protection requirements
   - CCPA (California) - Consumer privacy
   - HIPAA (US) - Health information
   - PCI-DSS - Payment card data
   
   Collection Authority:
   - Consent - Voluntary agreement
   - Warrant - Court authorization
   - Employer policy - Workplace searches
   - Incident response - Emergency circumstances
   
   Cross-Border Issues:
   - MLAT (Mutual Legal Assistance Treaties)
   - CLOUD Act (US law for overseas data)
   - Data localization requirements
   
   Privilege Concerns:
   - Attorney-client communications
   - Work product doctrine
   - Fifth Amendment (self-incrimination)
   ```

DETECTION INDICATORS:
- Evidence meets admissibility standards
- Expert properly qualified
- Testimony clear and understandable
- Cross-examination handled professionally

COMMON PITFALLS:
- Gaps in chain of custody documentation
- Using jargon without explanation
- Overstating conclusions
- Not preparing for cross-examination
- Appearing defensive or evasive

FURTHER READING:
- Federal Rules of Evidence
- Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, 509 U.S. 579 (1993)
- NIST Guidelines on Digital Evidence
- SWGDE Best Practices
